Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Nanostructured Sapphire Optical Fiber for Sensing in Harsh Environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The excellent potential of sapphire optical fiber for sensing in harsh environments such as those encountered in advanced combustion-based energy generation systems for high operation efficiency and low emission has long been recognized. The lack of viable cladding on sapphire fiber for low-loss light transmission and fiber protection remains the roadblock to real-world applications. This project aims to develop a novel alumina cladding with highly organized nano-sized air channels on sapphire fiber and to understand the associated processing-structure-property-performance correlations for evanescent-field chemical sensing and measurements via a strategy of fiber coating with aluminum followed by its anodization. The success of the project has the potential to overcome the decades-old sapphire fiber cladding challenge as well as offer a myriad of opportunities to transformative sapphire fiber-optic technology especially for sensing under adverse conditions where silica fiber sensors are no longer suitable. This project is carried out in partnership between Stevens Institute of Technology and Fiberguide Industries, Inc.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The inability to fabricate stable and high-quality cladding of controlled optical properties severely hampers the design and development of sapphire fiber sensors for a host of applications, particularly in corrosive environments at high temperatures. This project aims to develop and evaluate nanostructured alumina cladding on sapphire fiber for evanescent-field chemical sensing and measurements. The main objectives are: (1) evaluation of the theoretical correlation between mode-field overlap and cladding nanostructure to guide cladding fabrication; (2) determination of the window of processing parameters for aluminum coating and anodization as well as scale-up at Fiberguide; and (3) establishment and understanding of the interplay between the cladding nanostructure and sensing performance in combustion environment using evanescent-field laser absorption and surface-enhanced Raman scattering as the detection modalities. This project is transformative in that it has the potential to resolve the bottle-neck cladding problem long-faced by sapphire fiber and that the resultant specialty optical fiber may well lead to significant development of sapphire fiber-optic technology. Furthermore, industrial partnership and international collaboration as an integral part of the research activities greatly enriches the educational and research training experiences of the doctoral, undergraduate and high-school scholars participating in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The potential of single crystal sapphire optical fiber has long been recognized for sensing in high-temperature, high-pressure, and chemically aggressive harsh environments such as those encountered in advanced gas turbines and coal gasification systems. While significant progress has been made in fabricating high quality sapphire fiber, there has been no breakthrough in the development of suitable fiber claddings, a thin overcoat that protects and enables optical waveguide in the sapphire fiber. Claddings of desired optical, chemical, structural, and thermal properties are essential to realize sapphire-based fiber-optic sensor devices for demanding applications. The objectives of this project are to advance an innovative growth strategy to fabricate nanoporous claddings on sapphire fiber, to investigate the processing-structure-properties-performance paradigm of the resultant nanostructured sapphire optical fiber (NSOF), and to explore the integration of Au nanostructures within the nanoporous cladding for sensing measurements at elevated temperatures. The significant outcomes are summarized as follows.

We have developed a robust process to grow anodized aluminum oxide (AAO) cladding on sapphire fiber by first coating the fiber with aluminum metal film via dip-coating or thermal evaporation, followed by anodization of aluminum. In collaboration with Fiberguide Industries Inc, we have shown that the fiber coating process can be scaled up using a commerical fiber draw tower, paving the way for potential commericialization of the fabrication process.

Through numerical simulations, we have revealed strong correlation between nanostructure features of the AAO cladding (i.e., pore channel diameter and interpore distance) and the mode-field overlap (i.e., mode area and field strength) of the guided modes of NSOF. Theoretically and experimentally, we have demonstrated the significant advantage of AAO cladding on sapphire fiber over its unclad counterpart for improved evanescent-field sensing.

We have produced aluminum anodization diagrams that correlate the AAO pore diameter, interpore distance and porosity with the acid type, concentration and applied voltage. The fact that pore diameter and interpore distance have a fairly linear dependence on applied voltage and acid concentration makes tuning of the structure and hence the optical properties of AAO relatively straightforward. Higher applied voltage and larger acid concentration lead to faster AAO growth rate and thereby larger pore diameter and interpore distance. These results form an important knowledge base for the understanding, control, and subsequent scale-up of the NSOF fabrication.

We have illustrated, thermodynamically and kinetically, that the metal nanostructures (e.g., nanoparticles of Pd, Au, Ag and nanorods of Au) embedded in the nanopore channels of AAO exhibit unusual shape and mass stability at elevated temperatures. These properties make NSOF a robust fiber optic platform to incorporate functional nanostructures for novel sensing schemes for harsh environments.

We have developed an innovative in-situ deposition method for Au nanorod growth inside of the AAO nanopore channels. Using NSOF with embedded Au nanorods, we have shown, experimentally for the first time, that the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) of Au nanorods exhibits a strong dependence on temperature from room temperature to 800?C, in good agreement with our numerical simulations. This temperature-dependent property can be measured directly by monitoring the light transmission in the NSOF, which is a clear illustration of the effective coupling of near-field LSPR via the evanescent tunneling mechanism into the fiber waveguide core.

Overall, the project has established a wealth of knowledge on the processing-structure-property-performance interrelations for the fabrication and applications of a new class of sapphire specialty optical fiber. The innovative device designs and architectures enabled by the unique NSOF structure, as demonstrated by embedding Au nanorods in the AAO cladding pore channels and the resultant robust temperature response of LSPR will lead to a myriad of exciting new opportunities to explore novel sapphire fiber optic sensing modalities for fundamental and applied studies especially in harsh environments where conventional silica-based fiber optic sensors are no longer suitable.

This project has resulted in five peer-reviewed journal articles, one manuscript under peer review, one invention disclosure, numerous contributed and invited presentations, and completion of two doctoral dissertations. The research results have also been incorporated as case studies in two graduate courses taught by the principal investigator.
